hints.content:

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/8f7b778c08b757d05188c66668ba420e06fc1820)

The result is point $E$.
**Point $E$ is the reflection of point $A$ across the $x$-axis.**

question.content:
The point $A$ has coordinates $(0,6)$.  

**What point do we get when we reflect $A$ across  the $x$-axis?**

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/4790bc622b8d014d8debb5fb7a96203b3ed26265.png)

[[☃ radio 1]]

hints.content:
Since we are reflecting across the $x$-axis, the distance point $A$ is to the $x$-axis will stay the same.

But point $A$ is already on the $x$-axis, so the distance from point $A$ to the $x$-axis is $0$. Point $A$ doesn't move at all!
Point $A$ is its own reflection across the $x$-axis.

question.content:
The point $A$ has coordinates $(4,-6)$.  

**What point do we get when we reflect $A$ across  the $y$-axis?**

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/e21ba31b022ac599e3f0eff2ca38c0d9fb041ff2)

[[☃ radio 1]]

hints.content:
Let's consider the reflection across the $x$-axis first.

Since we are reflecting across the $x$-axis, the $\blue{\text{distance point $A$ is to the $x$-axis}}$ will stay the same, but will be  $\pink{\text{flipped to the opposite side}}$.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/7930c0f323217fd03a4575ab48f52ea2b0aca3c0)

Now we are at point $C$, but we still need to reflect across the $y$-axis.

Now we reflect across the $y$-axis.  So, the distance point $C$ is to the $y$-axis will stay the same.

But point $C$ is already on the $y$-axis, so the distance from point $C$ to the $y$-axis is $0$. Point $C$ doesn't move at all! 

*Fun fact: when we reflect across both axes one after the other, the order doesn't matter.*
Point $C$ is the reflection of point $A$ across the $x$-axis and then the $y$-axis.

Since we are reflecting across the $y$-axis, the $\blue{\text{distance point $A$ is to the $y$-axis}}$ will stay the same, but will be  $\pink{\text{flipped to the opposite side}}$.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/da57d3fe04687643296d24dcaf7f85706f3961a4)

Now we are at point $C$, but we still need to reflect across the $x$-axis.

Now we reflect across the $x$-axis.  So, the distance point $C$ is from the $x$-axis will stay the same.

But point $C$ is already on the $x$-axis, so the distance from point $C$ to the $x$-axis is $0$. Point $C$ doesn't move at all! 

*Fun fact: when we reflect across both axes one after the other, the order doesn't matter.*
Point $C$ is the reflection of point $A$ across the $y$-axis and then the $x$-axis.

question.content:

hints.content: Since we are reflecting across the $x$-axis, the $\blue{\text{distance point $A$ is from the $x$-axis}}$ will stay the same, but will be  $\pink{\text{flipped to the opposite side}}$.

$\blue{A}$ is $3$ units *below* the $x$-axis, so its reflection is $3$ units *above* the $x$-axis.  

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/c8291e351ad9b502255c1acbc2cea00fa60906e1)


The reflected point is $(3, 3)$.

*Fun fact: when we reflect across the $x$-axis, the sign on the $y$-coordinate changes.*

The correct graph is shown below.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/23bef4543812a8d5ddabc5bcd6027d515ae07c61)

question.content:
**The point $B$ is a reflection of point $A$ across which axis?**

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/fa333dc346c1754589f201b28fcbd7e410ea4910.png)

[[☃ radio 1]]

hints.content:
When we reflect a point across an axis, the $\blue{\text{distance between the point and the axis}}$ stays the same but is $\pink{\text{flipped to the opposite side}}$.

Since point $A$ and point $B$ are in diagonal quadrants, point $B$ cannot be a reflection of point $A$ over just the $x$-axis or just the $y$-axis.

Let's reflect point $A$ across both axes, and see if we get point $B$.

First, we'll reflect across the $x$-axis.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/ac3572827072dd7e02805dbf01fd37ec9b92982f)


Next, we'll reflect across the $y$-axis. 

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/428a5babeae90a3aeef242b88c281d6cf70dd761)

*Fun fact: when we reflect across both axes one after the other, the order doesn't matter.*
Point $B$ is a reflection of point $A$ across the $x$-axis and then the $y$-axis.

Point $B$ is a reflection of point $A$ across the $x$-axis and then the $y$-axis.

question.content:
**The point $B$ is a reflection of point $A$ across which axis?**
